comments.commentBody: The entire NSA outrage is straight out of Orwell. Big Brother IS watching! And too many Americans feel good about that.

Well in our day and age, the situation of someone being good in humanities and math/science is very rare. Typically the arts/humanities students avoid math and science as plague and usually do not try to master it. Arts and humanities are not a waste of time. But as a former physics major who took humanities, I believe studying for these classes is easier than for technical classes. You typically do the reading, think about it and then maybe write a paper or a report. Sometimes you have exams as well.

In math and sciences you really need to work hard to master the material and then apply it on assigned problems. You typically have challenging homework every week; you have exams and perhaps a small research paper. Plus technical majors are usually required to take normal humanities classes and most people don't complain. On the other hand, students in humanities take watered down "Science for Idiots" classes and complain about them.

That is why I believe humanities are considered easy :)

Sadly it's not just this country. Go back and look at some of the bullish remarks about the humanities made by Margaret Thatcher. Her influence has had a negative effect on British Education as well.

It's all about science and technology at the expense of the humanities. The idea is that you should train for "real" jobs - even though a lot of them have been outsourced anyway.

Indeed. Philosophy students get more training in critical thinking that perhaps any other major, including science majors.

Maybe I'm impractical, but critical thinking skills seem like they'd have practical uses in science and engineering problem solving, legal cases, political issues, medical diagnosis, business contracts, etc -- not just contemplating one's navel.

Some of the commenters make snide remarks about arts, humanities, and philosophy. They are of the opinion they are easy, a waste of time, and should not be taken by serious college students. When did this attitude form that arts and sciences do not go hand in hand? When did the attitude form that humans are not to be well-rounded?
One of our greatest artists was also one of our great scientists, Leonardo Da Vinci. One of our founding fathers was an architect, writer, politician, statesman, farmer, scientist, collector, and violin player (he invented the music stand.) This was Thomas Jefferson.
In the past, scientists were poets and artists, artists were engineers and architects. Why in the world do we think, in this country, that one nullifies the other?

Sorry but I don't agree it was the Supreme Being who put devolution on the menu. It was the people who run this place (call them devils if you like) who want the public so desperately confused that they will willingly give up their constitutional rights.

Years ago an enterprising scientist ran a gambling experiment with pigeons, by providing levers that the birds must strike to produce food pellets. When the timing and rewards form a pattern, lever action matches hunger. When the pellet delivery was random, the pigeons went crazy, and filled their cages with piles of food.

Humans are at a primitive stage in our evolution, as Zen monks like to point out. It will take thousands of years to even accurately evaluate our silly behavior.

Beach Ball Chris Christie will be recalled with gallows humor by future historians. They will be pondering how the human race even made it that far, since our leaders want us to return to bird brain behavior.

Let's sit back and enjoy it, since the Supreme Being has put devolution on the menu for a while. We may not be the ones to bounce back from that one, but who cares?
John McCain's strength has always been his uniquely qualified grasp of foreign policy. Unfortunately most of it is wrong.

In theory the ACA will be as efficient as single payer or even superior to single payer. To see how the system works in practice we need to observe it over the next two years. The old system was malfunctioning and dysfunctional. The ACA system is one good way to fix it. What exactly is political about supporting a workable solution to a very serious problem?
It sounds to me that you're describing a person as extraordinary as Charles Blow, are you not?
Extraordinary and CLASSY!

Part of what I see is that the oppressed and/or endangered person or group not only has the task of persevering and surviving (and succeeding), but then is in the position of having the information to tell the rest of the world, including the oppressors and perpetrators, what is wrong with the system and how it might be improved -- it takes a lot of poise and patience and generosity, it seems to me, to do that, on top of the qualities already shown in accomplishing the first task.

Deb, If anything, these two THURXWDP constructing co-conspirators should apologize to us for this nightmarish mish mosh that proved to be a far worse mix than mere OIL and WATER...PERIOD!!!

Howie

"Hatred still lives in the hearts of so many."  So true and so sad.  Mr. Blow's op-ed mentions the overt 'lynching' of the young man, but there are daily events of lesser magnitude, but no less demeaning, that keep the culture of mean fomenting.  I see it and hear it all the time.  What can we expect from that group in our society (i.e. the 'keep your government hands off my social security sign-wavers') when they continue to elect politicians who then act to harm this group as well as the rest of us?  Stupidity and hatred are parts of the syndrome of 'mean' so prevalent in this country.

I have made a pact with myself to never let an overt racist, homophobic or otherwise unwarranted unkind act pass without calling it out. I have turned a blind eye in situations that required stepping up and said nothing. I have never gotten over the shame that I felt at my weakness. That will never happen again. Bad things persist in occurring when good people do nothing. (to paraphrase the wise words of someone else.)

Oh boy. Reading again about the horrific murder of Mr. Byrd just gave me chills. Again. It is hard to fathom how people could be so cruel. I have never forgotten about this murder. It affected me in a way that I cannot explain.

I was also reminded of another cruelty while driving through Laramie, WY. What they did to poor Matthew Shepard was equally heinous.

And all because someone dare lead a life they want. Or differ in race. Or simply differ.

We think we have come so far. But not really. Hatred still lives in the hearts of so many. And the kids are not learning. Bullying is rampant.

We live in a culture of mean.
SD--the next-to-last sentence:  "In the end, it isn’t really about me anymore, even if we have agreed to raise them in a Jewish home."

This was in the works long before 911.

Bush's Daddy was the head of the CIA.

Then we had Bush Jr. who turned the USA economy over to the military industrial complex.

Before you totally blame Obama . . . . . . .

@Linda,

The security state is not constructed by or for every individual with a net worth in excess of a particular sum. It is driven by powerful institutions and the way business is done in and by the USA.

Think about Jim Crow (or white privilege in the present). Although an inconsequential white schmoe benefited from and probably argued for it, Jim Crow sustained itself and operated as a system.

Very powerful actors, like certain billionaire campaign contributors whose names we know or organizations like ALEC or the Heritage Foundation, visibly impel the fascist state, but it is the system that produces them, not these entities individually, that is the source and beneficiary of their power.

Bill, I won't argue with you over that.  My objection is to your use of the 1% terminology.  I, and I think many others, take it literally, to refer to a specific group of people who realize a certain level of income.  (I am not one of them, by the way.). It seems to me that you, and others, use it to refer, instead, to a cabal made up of people and/or organizations at a very rarified power level.  I see nothing to gain in incidentally demonizing the literal 1% over an issue that clearly cuts across party and income lines.

@Linda,

Have you seen this video?

The difference in the wealth and political power of the 1% and everybody else is not an exaggeration.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=QPKKQnijnsM

Nor are the confluence of the financial interests of the 1% and the foreign policy of the USA.

If Edward Snowden hadn't let us know, spying on everyone in the world would be continuing right now in secret.

Remember the Boland Amendment that prohibited arming and supporting Contra terrorists in El Salvador?

That "program" continued illegally, as will NSA spying if it is prohibited by Congress or the courts.

The American people are, from the perspective of the 1%, a dangerous enemy lusting for participatory democracy, and the American ruling class -- and their military -- are scared to death of the millions of friends and relatives of people they have tortured and killed in developing economies, as well as the millions of people whose economies and resources they have "secured" -- stolen -- for American banks and corporations.

Stasi-style spying is not to protect the American public.

It is to protect powerful actors who steal every penny they can from Americans as well as everybody else in the world.

I was a Chicago Black Hawk fan in the early 60s,  and an admirer of the team's "enforcer" Reggie Flemming.  When Flemming died not long ago his family reported that for many years he had suffered from traumatic brain injury.  I won't return as a hockey fan until the NHL cleans up the violence.
Not to be negative but I don't exactly think that is grounds for laughter...........

"..The difference between a depression and a severe recession are not just semantic. Recessions occur when the Federal Reserve raises interest rates in an effort to slow down an overheated economy. Most importantly, recessions end when the Fed lowers interest rates. In a recession the pent-up demand for housing and durable goods means that monetary policy alone can cure the recession. Just as antibiotics can be effective against bacterial infections but not against viruses, monetary policy alone cannot end a depression. Furthermore, modest fiscal stimulus and the automatic stabilizers that can hasten the end of recessions cannot end a depression. There can be ups and downs in the unemployment rate during a depression. However, the unemployment rate remains elevated. It was 14.5% in 1940 and 9.7% in 1941.

If we are in a recession, economic activity will fully resume just from the monetary and fiscal stimulus that has already occurred. Ultimately interest rates will rise. However, if we are in a depression, even one with safety-net benefits that mitigate the hardships, interest rates will remain relatively low for decades as was the case in Japan and the USA of the 1930s, where only World War II ended the depression.

Depressions occur after investment bubbles burst. In free-market capitalism, capital generates income for the owners of the capital which in turn is used to create additional capital. This is very good. Sometimes, i..."
http://seekingalpha.com/article/1543642

This THURXWDP fiasco came to us through the discourtesy of George "Calling All Men To BARANYs" and partner in crime, Michael "Shteyman...Don't go!"

WHH
Pre Unwinding?  Prelude to the Unwinding? Good point!
Isn't unwinding the wrong term?  That implies they are starting to sell the portfolio they've amassed.   But it seems they're just slowing down the buying. ?

Your math defies my understanding. Actually giving that much away to every person would bring down the US financial system and probably devalue the dollar so quickly that the grant would be worth a far smaller amount in euros or whatever currency still existed at that point. And I wish the banks did have 75 trillion set aside as it would mean there was a lot of money to draw on through any number of means.

Like you I hate the disparity of wealth but you should check your facts and reasoning.

Mr. Bernanke is certainly the darling of Wall Street and it wouldn't be surprising if his loving speculating fraternity would procure a statue of him to stand next to the bull that they have immortalized up until now.

As for the crowd of citizens living hand to mouth with nary a sign of ever having some of the cheap Bernanke no-interest money to speculate with he is reviled as a Wall Street toady who lives far from the madding crowd in an ivory tower without the slightest idea that a Main Street of ordinary people also exists and that they earn no interest on their hard earned retirement savings.

Actually, the report has little to nothing to do with the Fourth Amendment, and nowhere does the report conclude that any of the NSA programs violate the Fourth Amendment.

In some respects, that makes this report more important. The report does not recommend merely that government policy should comply with the constitution - that recommendation would be legally trivial. The report recommends that government policy should exceed constitutional guarantees - as one of the authors, Richard Clarke, put it, "just because we can do it doesn't mean we should."

I hope that this report is the first step toward a greater sensitivity to privacy - that, in a technologically advanced age, mere adherence to constitutional minimums is not enough.

I also hope that our sensitivity to privacy extends beyond government spying to corporate spying. Massive data collection by private enterprises not constrained by constitutional guarantees can be just as insidious and corrosive of public trust as massive data collection by our federal government.

politicsbyeccehomo.wordpress.dom

Limits on NSA activities is a good thing.  Yet, underneath it all, It's appalling that the human condition is such that agencies have to be created primarily to prevent one set of humans from destroying another set of humans.  Ideally, as we go about protecting outselves, we should also go about trying to uncover and understand the human factors involved that create warring hearts and minds, as well as, the human factors involved that create peaceful hearts and minds. Then somehow someway begin work, as a global family, to replace the negatives with the positives, one person at a time, if necessary; thus allowing peace on earth to be more than sentiments expressed on a greeting card or in the lyrics of a songs.  At least, one can dream.
It's worked to be extraordinarily profitable for some, and the President has shown us these are the kind of people he likes to surround himself with.

I don't believe President Obama would be changing anything if it weren't for Edward Snowden informing the public about the NSA's secret activities. I further don't think he will make any major changes after this report. He is a prisoner of the "all terror all the time" mentality and its now powerful bureaucracy, afraid to be perceived as relaxing on security in case someone attacks us and he would be blamed. It's easier for him to erode civil liberties and try to contain the damage.

Thank you, Edward Snowden. Simple principles of democracy are slowing being restored after being systematically eroded by a paranoid government that suggests it is protecting us but in fact is profiling us. I'm willing to risk the dangers that world presents in order to keep my private life private. I love my country - sometimes it does not seem to care for me.
I'd be the first to contribute to a fund for an Edward Snowden Research Library.

The issue is broader than "if you haven't done something wrong don't worry.". if everyone's is monitored, then everyone's "free" media, Supreme Court Judges elected officials and whistle blower's to journalist are also monitored.

There is a good deal of damaging, embarrassing, or private information that could be gained from a law abiding person such as a call to suicide hot line, abortion clinic, alcohol rehab center, Cancer center, etc.

Just as we have seen the IRS give different treatment based on organizations politics, the surveillance infrastructure could be misused as it has been to monitor the ex-wives and lovers of NSA employees. Additionally if the nature of our government changed significantly, the surveillance infrastructure could be used as a tool to crack down on government criticism and political enemies.

So far domestic terrorism has killed far fewer annually than care accidents even in the year of 9/11. While there was alarming talk of potential weapons of mass destruction, we have not seen terrorist substantial use them here. I'll keep my Bill of Rights and take my chances with the terrorist.

Lastly, if you are willing to give up your own privacy, please help other people keeps theirs. Unfortunately there is not an opt-out list for government monnitoring

John

Maybe I'm hallucinating, but I recall Obama campaigning in 2008 against the Patriot Act, FISA, NSA, & etc., and making strong statements about returning to the essential meaning of the Bill of Rights.

Turns out, being a Constitutional lawyer means being skilled in finding ways to subvert it.

No. I mean, where is the 4th amendment? Is there such a thing anymore? The whole thing hinges on what is a reasonable expectation of privacy. Web browsing from a home isn't a public activity.

People don't vote on this issue but they may start to vote on this issue. It's nuts to think that Verizon Wireless shared all of my browsing with the National Security Agency.

Not enough. Not nearly enough.

The monitoring of e-mail messages and e-documents is an even more unequivocal, and more egregious, violation of the Fourth Amendment. E-mail is electronic mail, and e-documents are electronic documents. E-mail and e-documents are indistinguishable --in any ethically, legally, or politically meaningful way--from the non-electronic mail and non-electronic documents ("Papers") that the Framers protected from arbitrary search in the Fourth Amendment.

The monitoring of e-mail messages, e-documents, and Website access must end. And must end immediately.
